Dear Mr. Powell:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

ALLEGATION:
Resident was brought to ER by police after she attempted to run in traffic. Since
resident is a minor, a guardian must be present while in the ER. Agency staff was
aware, but they were unable to stay with resident in the ER until placement could be
secured.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was transferred from Centralized Intake to the Division of Child
Welfare Licensing for investigation. The complaint noted the following,
Youth A (14) is a foster youth. The Foster Care Worker is a foster care case
manager from Family Service and Children's Aid in Jackson County. Youth A
was placed from Henry Ford Allegiance (Jackson) to Glens House crisis
residential (Kalamazoo) on Friday 8/21/20. On 8/22/20, Youth A eloped from
Glens House and was brought to the ER by police after she attempted to run in
traffic. The Foster Care Worker did briefly come to the ER, but left yesterday
around 6 PM. She was told that since the patient is a minor, a guardian must be
present throughout her stay in the ER. The Foster Care Worker acknowledged
that, but stated their agency is not equipped to staff someone in an ER 24/7. She
did offer that the on-call foster care worker would be available at any time to
return to sign paperwork, etc. The Foster Care Worker stated that she or her
supervisor had reached out to Jackson Co. CPS in regard to getting someone
here with the patient, but still today no one is here with this minor. The foster care
agency is aware that Youth A is not safe to leave the ER, but they are unable to
stay with Youth A in the ER until placement can by secured.
The complainant was not available, however, complainant 2 was familiar with this
case and was able to verify information. Complainant 2 was then interviewed via
phone on 08/24/20 and confirmed the information in the allegations. The
complainant reported that the agency staff was there at the time of the call on
08/24/20 and had been there since the night before.
I interviewed the Supervisor, Director, and Chief Administrator via phone conference
on 08/26/20. The Foster Care Worker was on unrelated planned leave during this
time. The Supervisor reported that Youth A was placed at the hospital on 08/22/20
and the Foster Care Worker was present at the hospital. While at the hospital, Youth
A was destructive at the hospital (destroyed property and broke a corner molding off
and was hitting herself with it) and exhibiting self-harm. The hospital staff then
chemically restrained Youth A and put her in restraints. The Supervisor reported that
3

the Foster Care Worker stayed at the hospital and sat with Youth A while she was
asleep until she left from the hospital. The Supervisor reported that the Foster Care
Worker left contact numbers with the hospital staff in case they needed to reach
someone. During the time after the Foster Care Worker left the hospital on the
evening of 08/22/20, until approximately 8:30pm on 08/23/20, the Supervisor
reported that she was in contact with the hospital and also spoke with Youth A and
no one from the hospital told her that a staff was needed at the hospital. Per the
Supervisor, Chief Administrator, and Director, the Supervisor went up to the hospital
at about 10:30pm on 08/23/20 and there has been staff there since that time. The
Chief Administrator reported frustration with the hospital staff for their lack of
communication on this.
I interviewed the Foster Care Worker via phone on 10/21/20. The Foster Care
Worker reviewed this incident and reported that Youth A was at the hospital and the
Foster Care Worker was present. Per the Foster Care Worker, Youth A was
chemically restrained to keep her calm and was in a locked room for security and
safety after she was acting out and self-harming at the hospital. The Foster Care
Worker noted that Youth A was sleeping, and the Foster Care Worker attempted to
speak with the hospital social worker who was unavailable for a long period. The
Foster Care Worker reported that she provided the hospital social worker phone
numbers for the on-call worker and the Supervisor and then left the hospital. This
was after Youth A was sleeping and the hospital social worker confirmed there were
no forms to be signed. The Foster Care Worker confirmed that the hospital staff told
her that a staff from the agency needed to be at the hospital with Youth A, but the
Foster Care Worker told the hospital that the agency did not have the staff to provide
24/7 staffing. The Foster Care Worker said that she did not know what transpired
after that as she was on a planned leave.
Documentation reviewed is as follows with applicable information noted:
 MiSACWIS case information inclusive of social work contacts
 Emergency staff coverage for Youth A at the hospital provided by the
Supervisor
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12207 Staff responsibilities.
(3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
directly responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care.
Social service workers shall work directly with the children, their
families, and other relevant individuals and be primarily
responsible for the development, implementation, and review of
service plans for the children and their families.
4

ANALYSIS: The agency is in violation of the rule as the Foster Care Worker
left Youth A at the hospital without staff supervision after being
directly told by the hospital that an agency staff was required to
be there. The youth was not admitted to the hospital at that time,
and this did not demonstrate sufficient supervision or
collaboration with other individuals involved with the child’s
case.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings in this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the agency submitting an
acceptable corrective action plan for the noted violation.
